text: Mutation of <extra_id_0> Jak3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in a patient with SCID : essential role of <extra_id_0> Jak3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in lymphoid development .

Males with X - linked severe combined immunodeficiency ( XSCID ) have defects in the common <extra_id_0> cytokine receptor gamma chain <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> gamma c <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) gene that encodes a shared , essential component of the receptors of <extra_id_0> interleukin-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) , <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-7 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> IL-9 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> IL-15 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

The Janus family tyrosine kinase <extra_id_0> Jak3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is the only signaling molecule known to be associated with <extra_id_0> gamma c <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , so it was hypothesized that defects in <extra_id_0> Jak3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> might cause an XSCID-like phenotype .
A girl with immunological features indistinguishable from those of XSCID was therefore selected for analysis .

An Epstein-Barr virus ( EBV ) - transformed cell line derived from her lymphocytes had normal <extra_id_0> gamma c <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression but lacked <extra_id_0> Jak3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein and had greatly diminished <extra_id_0> Jak3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> messenger RNA .

Sequencing revealed a different mutation on each allele : a single nucleotide insertion resulting in a frame shift and premature termination in the <extra_id_0> Jak3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> JH4 domain and a nonsense mutation in the <extra_id_0> Jak3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> JH2 domain .

The lack of <extra_id_0> Jak3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression correlated with impaired B cell signaling , as demonstrated by the inability of <extra_id_0> IL-4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to activate <extra_id_0> Stat6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the EBV-transformed cell line from the patient .

These observations indicate that the functions of <extra_id_0> gamma c <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are dependent on <extra_id_0> Jak3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and that <extra_id_0> Jak3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is essential for lymphoid development and signaling .
